title: Reverse 2048
description: Write C++ code for a program that reads in an unknown number of “Reverse 2048” games. The program must then use an algorithm to solve each of the solvable puzzles given in the input file

Reverse 2048 is a variation of the classic 2048 puzzle game, a sliding tile game that is played on a 4×4 grid. Unlike the original game, where the goal is to merge tiles to reach 2048, in Reverse 2048, the player must divide tiles to reach the smallest possible value, typically tile 2. The game is played using numerical tiles, each having values that are powers of 2. The main rules of the game are:

timeline.description: Develop a C++ program that can solve any given configuration of Reverse 2048 based on specified project requirements and constraints. Since the game requires a different strategic approach than traditional 2048, implementation must optimize moves to reach the smallest tile possible (tile with a value of 2) before the board becomes full.

The board consists of a 4×4 grid initially filled with 2 tiles having a value of 2048. New tiles appear after each move, following a random pattern. The new tiles have large numerical values of either 2048 or 1024 (no tile value lower than this should appear on the grid)

Players can slide all tiles in a chosen direction (left, right, up, down). When two tiles of the same value collide, they merge into one tile with half the value. For example, Two 2048s combine into a 1024, Two 1024s combine into a 512, and so on, all down to two 4s combine into a 2. A move is valid only if at least one tile can be merged or moved.
The game is won if a tile of value 2 is reached before the board becomes full. The game is lost if there are no valid moves left.

Develop two different algorithms that will play Reverse 2048 against each other. The selected algorithms will exclusively be referred to as Alg 1 and Alg 2. The two algorithms will play against each other on separate boards at the same time. The game will start at the same spot on the both boards. The first algorithm to complete the game will be considered the winner. A maximum of 1000 moves per game per algorithm is allowed. If this limit is exceeded, the game ends as unsolved.
The file holding the configurations is called reverse 2048.txt. An example of the input would be as follows: 512 , 3 (a game of reverse 512 on a board size of 3 × 3)

function.title: Board Representation
function.description: The game board is represented as a 2D vector - vector<vector<int>> gridAlgOne, gridAlgTwo. Empty cells are represented by 0 and occupied cells by their respective tile values. There are variables to keep track of Move count (max 1000), Empty cell count, Win condition (presence of tile 2), No-move condition.

function.title: Algorithm 1 – Greedy Reduction Strategy
function.description: Simulate all four directions and select the move that reduces the maximum tile value the most.

function.title: Algorithm 2 – Strategic Minimax Strategy
function.description: Each possible first move is done then is evaluated, from the resulting board the algorithm simulate all possible second moves and record their resulting scores. Throughout the process The algorithm computes Worst-case score (maximum), Best-case score (minimum), Risk factor (worst − best), Average future potential. These values help compute strategic value, the move with the lowest strategic value is selected.

function.title: Movement Logic
function.description: If the neighboring cell in the movement direction is empty, The tile slides into that position. If two adjacent tiles have equal values, they merge into a single tile with half the value. The merged tile cannot merge again in the same move, to prevent a tile from merging multiple times in a single move, The game tracks recently merged tiles using borderNeighbourWhoWasMerged, Before merging, checkIfElementWasChanged() ensures the tile has not already merged this turn. After each valid move, a new tile of max value is added to a random empty cell on the board. A second sweep removes any remaining gaps, ensures all tiles are fully compacted in the movement direction.

function.title: Move Evaluation
function.description: Before committing to a move, the game evaluates its impact using evaluateMove(direction, grid). The function clone the original grid and stores the value in a previousScore (sum of all tiles before move) variable and simulates the move on the clone and is store in newScore(sum of all tiles after move) variable - this my way of measuring progress

function.title: Recently Viewed Products
function.description: To enhance user experience, the site tracks and displays the last 10 products a user has viewed, persisting across browser sessions. When a user clicks on a product, its unique ID is added to a queue stored in the browser's local storage. This queue follows a First-In-First-Out (FIFO) principle with a limit of 10 items. Upon each homepage visit, the list of IDs is sent to the backend. The server fetches the latest product details (e.g., price, availability) for each ID, ensuring the user always sees current information.

function.title: Product Detail Page
function.description: A single API request fetches the core product object (name, price, image, etc.). The backend service then enriches this object by merging related data from other database tables, such as seller information, category details, and customer reviews, before sending the complete payload to the frontend.

function.title: Product Recommendations
function.description: For All Users (Category-Based), Recommendations are generated by scoring products based on category overlap with the currently viewed item. Products sharing more categories receive a higher score and rank. For Logged-In Users (History-Aware), In addition to category scoring, the system incorporates the user's browsing history and recently viewed products to create a more personalized and relevant recommendation list.

function.title: User Authentication (Login)
function.description: The user submits their email and password. The backend finds the user record by email, retrieves the stored (hashed) password, and verifies it against the provided password using a secure hashing algorithm ( bcrypt). On successful verification, a JSON Web Token (JWT) is generated. This token, valid for 12 hours, contains encrypted user metadata (User ID, Name, Role, Cart ID) and is stored client-side in local storage to authorize subsequent requests.

function.title: User Registration
function.description: The frontend submits user details (name, email, password, etc.). The backend first checks for an existing account with the submitted email. If the email is new, the password is hashed for security, and a new user record is created. A unique, persistent shopping cart is automatically generated and linked to the new account, allowing users to save items across sessions.

title: Rydly
